The fall of the Mughal Empire, which ruled large parts of the Indian subcontinent from the early 16th to the mid-18th century, was caused by a combination of internal weaknesses and external pressures. Key factors include: Weak Successors: Following the reign of Aurangzeb (1658-1707), the empire was left with a series of weak and ineffectual rulers who lacked the ability to maintain control and enforce central authority. This led to a gradual loss of cohesion and discipline within the empire. Administrative and Military Decline: The administrative system became corrupt and inefficient. The once formidable Mughal military became outdated and unable to match the advances in military technology and tactics employed by European colonial powers and regional rivals. Economic Strain: Continuous warfare, especially during Aurangzeb\'s reign, depleted the empire\'s treasury. Heavy taxation to fund military campaigns placed a significant burden on the peasantry, leading to widespread discontent and economic instability. Religious and Social Policies: Aurangzebâ€™s policies of religious intolerance alienated large segments of the population, particularly Hindus and Sikhs. His destruction of Hindu temples and imposition of jizya (a tax on non-Muslims) fostered resentment and resistance. Rise of Regional Powers: The central authority of the Mughals weakened, allowing regional powers such as the Marathas, Sikhs, and Rajputs to assert their independence and challenge Mughal dominance. The Marathas, in particular, emerged as a formidable force, capturing large territories from the Mughals. European Colonial Expansion: The arrival and expansion of European colonial powers, especially the British and the French, significantly impacted the Mughal Empire. The British East India Company, through strategic alliances, military victories, and administrative control, gradually expanded its influence, culminating in the Battle of Plassey (1757) and the Battle of Buxar (1764), which decisively weakened Mughal power. Infrastructural Decay: The infrastructure, including roads and communication systems, deteriorated due to neglect and lack of maintenance, hampering effective governance and trade. Internal Rebellions and Civil Wars: Frequent rebellions by disgruntled factions within the empire, coupled with civil wars over succession, further destabilized the Mughal state. The empire became increasingly fragmented as various regions asserted their autonomy. The cumulative effect of these factors led to the gradual disintegration of the Mughal Empire, which became largely symbolic by the mid-18th century. The formal end of the empire came with the British exiling the last Mughal emperor, Bahadur Shah II, following the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
